pros:
My experience at Zendesk has been the best of my career. I've been supported in my career development and I work with some really wonderful, talented people.

The environment is generally collaborative without a lot of bureaucracy getting in the way of new ideas. Most employees are approachable and transparent and genuinely want to help each other succeed.

I love our global structure because I get to work and exchange ideas with coworkers all over the world and sometimes travel to collaborate in person. These connections across cultures have contributed greatly to my professional and personal growth.

Our benefits are excellent and our office spaces are beautiful and well taken care of. Learning & development is promoted on an individual and team level. Our events and holiday parties are really fun without being ostentatious.

I have amazing work/life balance; It's a real value here, not just lip service. I work 45 hours per week on average and my productivity is higher than jobs where I worked 60+ because I love what I do.
cons: Working in the Tenderloin is very stressful. As some employees have mentioned, voicing that you don't like coming here every day is dismissed by many as an insult to our neighbors. I reject that leap; I care a lot about the people who live here and I volunteer with and donate to local organizations. I also avoid coming into work because I do not feel safe. I've personally been grabbed by a stranger, stepped on used needles, heard gunshots, and seen several acts of violence- all within a few feet of our offices. We live in a city and I accept some level of risk and danger, but this is too much.
advice_to_mgmt:
Please take SF employees' safety concerns seriously and move the office to a safer neighborhood. We don't need to work in the Tenderloin to volunteer here and support local orgs.

Consolidate to one building in SF. Meetings rarely (if ever) start on time because someone is always running late from another building.

Continue to build on our Learning & Development offerings, including a lot more management training. Also offer training on specific skills. Survey the employees to find out what they need to learn to be successful.

Allow a reasonable amount of global travel. When employees build strong relationships with their peers in other countries it contributes immensely to the quality of work and productivity. You just can't make the same kind of connections over a Zoom call.

Stay humblident.

review_title: No longer the company it once was
pros:
- Very high work / life balance. I probably considered it one of the best especially for a Silicon Valley company
- Leadership team is very approachable
- Business is going strong, possibly due to a really strong sales team. Stock price keeps breaking record high all the time in the past couple months!
- Pretty good brand recognition. Customers are actually loving the product! I think it’s still pretty cool to have random people saying “Oh you’re working for Zendesk? I love you guys’ product, it helps my small business a lot!!”
- Global company, quite a good chance you’ll get to travel to see other offices around the world when you reach certain seniority level
- The standard Silicon Valley company’s perks: commuter benefits, snacks, 401k, health insurance, all the usual stuffs
cons:
- Especially in Engineering org, feels like there is zero accountability and no rewards. I’m not talking about punishing people for mistakes but you still have to have some sort of accountability. Projects can go on forever and people get stuck in one project for months if not years. At the same time, people who deliver good job are simply not rewarded.
- The classic “if everyone owns it, nobody owns it”.
- Lots of growing pains. People start to introduce processes, middle management, bogus KPI or goals, cost cutting exercise, etc.
- No clear direction for career advancement. It works really well if you’re already at Staff or Architect level but if you’re a junior trying to climb up the career ladder, it’s close to non existent.
- Total compensation seems to be much lower than industry standard, especially in Silicon Valley where a 10 people in-garage based startup is valued at some billion dollars and able to throw money to attract the best talents.
- I will repeat other reviews about office location. It can be daunting to go to work in such an environment every day. Again, this is not being ignorant to the real issue there but there is this mental stress you accrue subconsciously that will affect you. Some people can’t take it anymore, others manage to ignore it. Zendesk representative will probably respond to this message by saying that Zendesk is “committed” to work to improve the area but in my opinion there are various other way to still get involved and not making the location the office where all employees should go to
advice_to_mgmt: Really open your ears and listen to your employees. Get rid of the “I’ve been in the industry for X number of years” attitude. Never punish anyone for mistake but always reward a good work!

pros: There have been some amazing hires as of late at Zendesk who are lifting Zendesk up into the space it wants to be in. Specifically the CIO who's been fantastic thus far. There's also much hope and optimism about the company's future and a general consensus feeling that the company is currently in a good place. Business is all good.
cons:
Zendesk's core company values are a complete facade. Many of the people who formed it's once 'humble' culture have now departed and have been replaced by a very mid to senior level hierarchy. I can't count how many VP's and Directors have been hired in the past 2 years but they all report into maybe 3-4 people which creates a ton of friction because of the lack of communication and egos this structure has created.

I echo many of the reviews on here that favoritism is a huge problem at Zendesk which is preventing the company from becoming more modern and data driven. A rat pack group sits atop the social pyramid at Zendesk who have been there since the early days and who are too comfortable to move. They use antiquated data tools and are failing to adapt to a more data driven culture. As a result, no resources are given to many of the technical analytic groups because they've gotten to where they are going on gut, not data. It frustrates analysts across departments because they do not know how their product is performing and can't make informed business decisions.

Finally, Neighborhood wise, the Tenderloin wears on you over time. In ways I felt it affected my job performance because on bad days I refused to leave the building for a walk and couldn't stride into work without having some level of anxiety because of the conditions. This is not to say that Zendesk is not empathetic to the neighborhood, but rather the conditions accentuate the stress in the work environment.
advice_to_mgmt:
Take a minute to evaluate your company structure and determine if expanding the mid-level leadership who have the vision but not the current technical skills is what will keep Zendesk successful. Many ideas, not enough execution. Intentions are good but unrealistic given the resources.

Get out of your comfort zone and recognize that problems exist within the product and data organizations. If Zendesk wants to expand and retain its stock price, it needs to put more investment into it's data infrastructure beyond what it has done so far. It is still a mess to wrangle with even with some reorganization.

review_title: Overall positive but has HUGE problems in my opinion
pros:
-Tons of Snacks
-Decent work life balance.
-MOST high level employees will recognize your hard work.
-For the most part great people to work with.
-Not too big of a company but not too small. Good work environment.

-They listen to employees and try to do better for the most part.
cons:
Neighborhood is very interesting to say the least. I understand there is a $120 parking benefit for Zendesk and I appreciate that. However, the Tenderloin is probably not the best place for a growing company. This is something employees cannot control and I know it is a huge negative about Zendesk. There is no way to sugar coat this.

Many employees that were here in the early stages of Zendesk are gone or pushed out. (Talking about employees that started before 2016). In order to survive at Zendesk, favoritism was something you better hope your management has for you. There was a recent hire where a Sr director decided to just build a team with people who use to work for her. This ultimately created a separation from the longer tenured employees and a huge level of favoritism.

The level of favoritism at Zendesk made it hard for my team to stay motivated and work harder. In my opinion, this has to be addressed. I understand there are people you prefer to work with, but it got to a point where if you didn't agree with the direction the team is heading towards. You will be placed in their cross hairs. I also understand change is something that is hard to adapt to. However, if employees in your team are unhappy and leaving one by one. I don't have much to say. That in itself is a red flag.
advice_to_mgmt:
I appreciate all the things management has done such as 401k match. 401k match was something that was not around until late 2017. Employees kept asking for it and they delivered. Although the 401k was not a lot, it just shows that management were willing to listen.

Favoritism has to be addressed. If you want people to work harder and be loyal to Zendesk. Leadership needs to realize a simple concept taught in elementary school. Treat others how you want to be treated.

review_title: Company Not "Buttoned Up" and Struggling with its 2nd Act!
pros: People are friendly and there is a strong, almost familial culture. In that vein there is a strong respect for family and work life balance relative to other tech companies in the bay area. While it varies by group working hours in the office typically start at between 9-10am. And most people leave between 5-6pm so there are very few folks around past 6:00pm. Compensation is generally lower than at other tech firms. But it is probably fair given the number of hours worked.
cons:
CHALLENGES MOVING UP MARKET
The company is going through a challenging transition as it moves from its early success being a help desk software platform for startups and smaller businesses to one that is now focused on moving up market and selling customer service software to larger more established businesses. Zendesk has promised Wall Street that it will achieve $1B in revenue by 2020. This is an aggressive goal that has put a lot of short term stress on the business (and correspondingly its employees) each quarter as it figures out how to live up to the promise.

To achieve $1B in my mind means fully committing to moving up market and selling to enterprise buyers. This has been hard for the company as it is requires the company to be the type of business that the original Zendesk was trying to disrupt. As Mikkel the CEO writes in his book Startupland "we shared a healthy disdain for the traditional enterprise software sales model. The big platforms, the expensive salespeople with the expense accounts, the semireligious conferences, the PowerPoint software, the locked-in relationships".

This move up market requires that requires the company to change a lot of what made it successful early on. The company needs to build new muscles in sales and marketing to support enterprise which requires new skills, new processes, and often times new people. This has resulted in multiple reorganizations (or "evolutions" as they are now calling them) in sales and marketing that have been fairly disruptive and caused a lot of angst for people in terms of having clear roles and responsibilities.

LACK OF URGENCY
The work life balance mentioned as a pro also means that the company does not move as quickly as other places. And as a result there is not a lot of "urgency" within the company to get stuff done quickly. This can be frustrating for those who do have urgency and are trying to push others to have the same mindset.

NOT A DATA/ANALYTICS CULTURE
The company has historically not been one that relied significantly on data/metrics to make decisions. It's always done things by the seat of its pants and is not particularly buttoned up. As a result there is not a strong data/analytics culture within the company and the corresponding data/analytics infrastructure including reporting and systems reflects that. So often the data required to make decisions is not available, incomplete, or simply inaccurate.
The company is trying to change this but it requires a lot of work to undo years of neglect. So for folks that want to have reliable data to make decisions Zendesk may not be the best fit.

DIVERSITY & CAREER ADVANCEMENT
While the company has initiatives around diversity the company is still not very diverse at the senior and mid level management positions and there seems to be a bias for younger employees. This seems to be ingrained into the companies recruiting culture. In fact two of its most senior and long tenured minority Vice Presidents just announced their departure October 2017. The company does have a history of promoting young employees who are willing to work hard and go the extra mile. There are at least 3 VPs that have been promoted in the last year that are under 30. Many of the older senior leaders are being pushed out.
advice_to_mgmt: Wall Street certainly rewards growth and setting an aggressive goal of $1B in revenue is to be commended. However, it also necessitates focusing on short term revenue goals which when you are trying to shift the business is challenging. I'd encourage management to think more about the long term strategy and providing enough air cover and protection to allow employees to invest in initiatives that will fuel the future growth of Zendesk.

review_title: Place is a Mess. Don't Come Here. Good People Gone/Leaving
pros:

The CFO is phenomenal.
cons:
Zendesk was known as one of the better tech companies to work for in the Bay Area, but it's gone downhill fast. It started with the hiring of the CRO, who just announced he's "leaving". This person either fired or pushed out key product, marketing and sales executives/leaders in the company within the last year. These roles are either not being filled, or being filled with people that do not embody the Zendesk culture of openness, collaboration and teamwork. Many key people in sales, product and marketing are actively looking to leave the company as we speak. Word is getting out fast that Zendesk isn't a desirable place to work.

Now that the CRO is gone, not sure how/if they company can recover from the major mess that was made because sales isn't hitting their numbers.

To add insult to injury, the office is located in the absolute worst part of town where crime is rampant. And if you think you can work remotely, think again - they want you sitting at your desk majority of the time.
advice_to_mgmt: Now that the CRO has left, and most of the good people in certain organizations (sales, marketing, product) are gone, take a look in the mirror and realize you've made a huge mess. You'll need to hire some excellent talent and oust some of the newer folks you've brought in that do not embody the Zendesk spirit. You probably want to meet with, and keep, the few good folks you have left.

review_title: A once great startup failing to make the leap to the next level
pros:
- The founders are terrific and really exhibit a lot of humility.

- World class creative design team. Terrific internal and external branding.

- Culture: There is no common DNA that binds the company culturally. The company has to emphasize on core values and have people in all levels of the organization “walk the walk”.
- Rampant cronyism/favoritism. If you are friends with the Sheriff, you can get away with anything in this town.
- "Flash" gets rewarded over substance
- Lack of transparency in senior leadership. Financial and headcount planning exercise lacks discipline and long term thinking.
- Engineering is treated as a disposable “resource” and full time employees get treated more like contractors.
- Product management dictates what gets done without necessarily doing due diligence. Most things are done by a product manager’s “gut” feel without the corresponding responsibility. Non-technical PMs trying to run engineering teams makes things double worse.
- The operations engineering organization is an absolute nightmare. Things take forever to get done and any efforts to fix this has not been effective.
- The company lacks long term strategic thinking and tends to follow industry leaders without being thought leaders.
- There has been a lot of attrition in the company in the past six months. There have been at least 10 people at the senior management level (VP+) who have left the company along with several tenured employees.
- The company was great a few years ago but is just not making the leap to the next level. Things have become extremely political, especially at the top. People put their interests ahead of the company’s. Really really sad.
advice_to_mgmt: Please stop cronyism in the company and establish a fair performance review process. Rethink top level management structure and reinforce accountability at all levels.

review_title: Passive-Aggressive Leadership, 'Cool Kids' Get Away with Everything, Narcissists Lurk Beware
pros:
• Flexible hours and work environment
• Attention paid for healthy work-family-life balance
• Nice snack options
• Access to a wide variety of technologies
• Back in the day, the 'chill factor' was great but high tension now
cons:
• Passive-Aggressive leadership
• No commitment to seasoned employees
• No follow-up or accountability on negative performance reviews, if they're one of the 'cool kids' - particularly, if they the 'cool kid' is in management
• High turnover and some aloof, ineffective managers that leave their team in disarray
• High turnover has encouraged sloppy hiring of people who name-drop and speak only in industry buzzwords with little comprehension or deep technical ability; narcissists are superb at charisma and conning, working their way up the social ladder
• Younger arrogant managers talking down to seasoned engineers and colleagues causing friction and lack of trust between teams and employees
• Huge attrition rates and technical debt with loss of great colleagues, now that we've gone public (IPO)
• Non-comparable pay for Silicon Valley, despite experience level and ability; high pay goes to the 'cool kids' with the 'flashy outfits' and "friends" in high places
• Candid but respectful voicing of concerns can either fall on deaf ears or receives secretive retribution towards the employee who brought up the issue; walking on eggshells has become a common theme behind the scenes
• Tribalism: certain groups receive all the goodies, attention and perks, while others are ignored; cliques are easily formed similar to high school or college
• Neighborhood environs are quite depressing and disturbing; they don't contribute to a positive start of the day, especially when I've had to witness shootings, stabbings, overdoses, public defecation, robbery and physical assaults - including of myself and my colleagues - just walking to and from work. When colleagues have brought up physical assaults and abuse they've received in the neighborhood, "Community Outreach" and upper management has downplayed their concerns and told them "maybe they should be more considerate of people in need" and "take a walking tour to better get to know the neighborhood" - they assume the worst of the person and negatively attack their character as non-charitable person. Of course, these same people don't live in the neighborhood, some don't even live in the city, are quick to dismiss employees fears and valid safety concerns, in the name of political correctness. Why do honest people need to be attacked?
advice_to_mgmt:
My advice to management is:

• to do more to keep and attract great quality employees and avoid falling into frat-boy style hiring tactics. Don't be fooled by loquaciousness and flashy titles. Make sure the 'cool kid' actually has substance and expertise in what they claim to be an expert in.

• Consider offering raises and/or bonuses for long-time employees who've put in the work, passion and loyalty to the company and their fellow team members.

• Don't allow resources to be gobbled up by some teams over others just because they're the popular and powerful. It creates an unbalanced and unfair work enviornment when some teams don't have the funds to complete training or beneficial off-sites because no one thought of them.

• Improve office security so that no more equipment, like laptops, or personal effects, like purses or wallets, are stolen.

pros:
Welcoming environment - this is the first company that I've worked for where office politics weren't at play on Day 1.

Enthusiastic staff - while workloads can be daunting, getting things done correctly is first and foremost on everyone's mind. The overall vibe is very team-centric.

Onboarding is a snap - I've had everything necessary to do my job since my first day in the office. This includes hardware (workstation and peripherals), software (operational applications, task-specific applications), security (right-sized access to data/tools) and mentoring (vast team knowledge and a role-related "buddy" to answer any questions). New hires need to get up to speed quickly, and this enables it.

Freedom to work where you are comfortable. Prefer a booth or a couch over sitting at your desk? No problem - there are plenty of different types of spots to settle in to get work done. Use of technology to meet also bridges communication gaps that are typically present in companies with teams that are literally based around the world.

Reduced overhead. Need a mouse? Get one. There's no need for a 5-day turnaround with requisitioning something that'd cost less than the time it would take to request it. Employees are enabled to make decisions and get things done that are in the best interest of the organization.
cons:
There is much work to be done - if you aren't accustomed to a fast-paced, constantly-changing environment, this can be exasperating. Fortunately, management has acknowledged this is and is in the process of right-sizing the organization for the workload.

Some people may be challenged by the open-concept office layout - if you come from a land of white noise and cubicle farms, there are plenty of audio and visual distractions to deal with.

Overall, this is still a green organization. Many employees have been with the company from the early days, so there is sometimes a lack of insight that could streamline procedures.

cons: Location - Mid Market area of SF can be a little sketchy
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the great work in growing an employee focused company with a conscious effort to help the community

pros: Zendesk can be a great place to work. The company is full of talented and genuine employees, and the office is well designed. The company has had plenty of real success. More importantly the brand is strong and the company truly cares about the community and giving back. Compared to other corporate software companies, I find Zendesk to be less pretentious and more fun.
cons:
I find the company positives to be lacking within the Marketing Department. A turnstile of executives have created a vacuum of true leaders. As a consequence, marketing teams are suffering. Despite reorg after reorg, we in marketing struggle to align on strategies, priorities or processes; inhibiting collaboration. Im leaving because the morale is low (rightfully so) and high quality employees are continually leaving.

Zendesk Marketing is in that awkward phase of not having the upside of the startup (equity, role and growth), but also doesn’t have the benefits of larger organizations. Choose your team, manager and department wisely. If done right, I’m hopeful Zendesk Marketing can figure it out and you can have a great employment… choose wisely.
advice_to_mgmt: By the time you read this, I’m hopeful the transition is over and there is a renewed emphasis on career planning, training and mentorship. If you’re brought in to fix these systemic challenges, my advice is to challenge the status quo, reward employees based on merit, and not show favoritism to institutional knowledge. I hope you can really push the leadership team to focus on employee satisfaction as much as customer satisfaction, as happy employees mean happy customers.

review_title: Great place to develop your career
pros:
Zendesk has been nothing but short of amazing to me. Leadership truly wants you to succeed. Building my career here has been nothing short of amazing. They will fully invest in you if you are willing to work.

Other insanely great perks:
RSUs & Stock Options
Unlimited PTO
Free Beer and Soda and Snacks
Awesome office on the Capitol Square
Happy Hours and fun parties
The people who work there!
Lunch and learns
cons: No 401K matching which kinda sucks, but can live with. There are some people who act like it's a high school.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep working with the people that put their all into making Zendesk great! Make sure that transparency is kept!

review_title: Positive Environment & Energy - No Plans to Leave
pros:
This is the first company in my career where I feel like I'm home and not keeping an eye out for other opportunities.

Clearly defined roles within the team at varying levels, including specific information about what is expected to be promoted within the same type of role or how to move to a different role.

Everyone is passionate about Zendesk and is honest about our strengths & areas for improvement -- there aren't any facades here.

I thoroughly enjoy our company town hall meetings. Mikkel's personality truly shines and is reflected in all of my peers.

Beautiful office space with all of the conveniences and luxuries you could dream of.

An international presence gives you the opportunity to work with others abroad and gain exposure to business practices outside of the US.

I like my co-workers, but do not feel pressured to be "best friends" with them as might be present in other similar environments. We're all mature and respect our space.
cons:
There is a significant amount of work required due to the aggressive goals, therefore, causing everyone to be stretched thin at times.

However, it hasn't been unnoticed by upper management - it's evident they're actively working to improve the situation by finding ways to better staff the org.

pros: Good boss. Decent challenges. Flexible PTO. Nice offices. Good budget. Work life balance is good. People are personable and friendly.
cons: Architecture feels creaky. Company is overly product feature oriented versus fixing what is broken. Engineers leave early. Leadership can and do play favorites with certain people.
advice_to_mgmt: Fix reliability issues and raise accountability.

pros: Solid work/life balance, career opportunities, the company has integrity and does great things for the community.
cons: No cons that I can think of so far.

pros:
* Relaxed culture including work hours, dress code, basically everything
* In-office perks like free coffee, soda, beer, and food makes office life even more enjoyable
* No jerks, everyone is friendly and interesting (that I've met so far)
* Employee stock ownership gives all of the employees a vested interest in performing and doing well
* ESPP and stock bonuses make for good compensation even though there is no 401k matching
* Lots of promotions being announced, so I'm assuming there is upwards mobility (full transparency, I've only been here 1 month)
cons:
* Some minor growing pains and technical debt (to be expected as we transition from a small startup to a larger publicly traded company)
* Some re-organizing is still in progress, which can be a little confusing as a new hire but this is trivial
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the good work!

pros: Upward mobility, great work/life balance
cons: Frequent changes to structure of sales org

pros:
- The Product... such a great product and the company is very product focused
- The culture. Everyone is real.
- A lot of opportunity to make really good money.
cons: Work/life balance... at least in Sales which is typically the case at every company.
advice_to_mgmt:
- clean up some of the cumbersome processes for teams to work together
- Preserve the culture of Zendesk feeling like Zendesk

review_title: Career paths ill defined in many business units
pros: Great work life flex, smart, nice people. Product is well built and customers love it. Offices are nice and perks pretty sweet.
cons: Decision making lacks transparency, favoritism runs rampant. There have been multiple org changes in the last 18 months and nothing seems to be working. If you are not part of the inner circle you will have a tough time making advances in your career. The path from Director and above is not well defined.
advice_to_mgmt: Walk the talk about transparency, listen to your employees. Be aware that people see how others are treated and be sure to treat people fairly.

review_title: Good place if you like beer
pros: Some smart folks here. All three buildings are within walking distance. Cell phone and commuter allowance. Company believes in putting the customer first.
cons: The business is more concerned with what kind of beer to stock in the cooler than turning a profit. Also, if you didn't vote for Hillary you will be chastised and looked down upon. That being said, if you are a liberal who likes beer you will love it here.
advice_to_mgmt: Get some leadership who have experience with running profitable companies rather than just dot-com startups. Less partying, more working.

pros: Amazing culture, great people to work with. Perfect work life balance. Great benefits; lot of activities.
cons: No 401K matching. No 100% free insurance. Sometimes climbing up the ranks is not very easy because of visibility issues.

pros: Culture allows you to truly be who you are. Colleagues take you at face value regardless of dress, value, beliefs etc.... product is scalable, intuitive, and easy to use. Executive leadership is extremely smart, hard-working, and focused.
cons: There's a shift in culture going on in the sales org. A culture of accountability and success. If we want to reach a billion dollars in 2020, failure is not an option. Personally, I am OK with a culture of accountability - It's surprising Zendesk has been this successful with the laissez-faire sales culture of the past. Its speaks to the power of the product.
advice_to_mgmt: Its going to be a delicate balance between a culture of accountability and turning into another VMware. Be careful not to lose the spirit of Zendesk. I think Mikkel will do a great job keeping his directs inline to protect his culture.

pros: Great product and mostly good people.
cons: Built their reputation as an SMB player and lately trying to move up the food chain to become an Enterprise player. They are not executing well on this move up and with the hire of a new CRO in mid 2016 they continue to make many mistakes. There has been a bit of an exodus since the new CRO has come on board with little hope that the changes being made will bring good results.

review_title: Grateful to work and grow here.
pros: Great culture, friendly and fun team, flexibility, decent benefits. Lovely place to be social, easily accessible by public transit. Corporate Social Responsibility team does great work, Volunteer opportunities highly encouraged.
cons: Lower than average salaries, fast-paced growth means tons of change all the time, the larger the company gets, the stricter the format of the roles.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue to hire for talent, inventiveness, diversity, and playfulness. Consider the local market value of your employees. Please keep funding CSR and ways for us to contribute to community and each other socially.

pros: Happy customers, design focused, good work/life balance.
cons: Internally very dysfunctional with significant morale issues that stem from a lack of focus, heavily embedded favoritism / politics, volatile operational deficiencies. Very little support for career growth for employees interested in metrics/performance based career advancement.
advice_to_mgmt: Have some tough, honest conversations about the changes that need to be made to improve employee morale & continue growth.

pros: Amazing product, great product development leadership
cons: Growing pains, post IPO environment, territory changes

pros: I can't speak for all departments, but the things I love most are the work/life balance,the company culture, and the fact that employees opinions and ideas are actually taken into consideration (regardless of the position level)
cons: With the company growing so quickly, some employees are constantly finding themselves having to adapt to the new changes; however, this is inevitable, and Zendesk does its best to make the transitions as easy as they can for their employees. Another thing I would add is the lack of 401K matching, but I'm sure this will come eventually.

pros: Amazing company, great location, happy employees, best manager I've ever had- did not want to leave, but school started back up again
cons: Absolutely nothing when it comes to the people, sometimes work became a little repetitive.

pros: Opportunities for advancement, ability to work with multiple teams, life/work balance
cons: A lot of first-time managers who don't know how to manage people and teams.
advice_to_mgmt: Arm these first-time managers with the tools and knowledge to become successful managers. Also, consider getting feedback from the manager's team to help with the manager's growth.

review_title: Collaborative Support Environment Allowing for Learning and Direct Input on a Support Platform
pros:
The Support organization at Zendesk is something special. We use our own product to serve our customers which allows us to spot bugs, provide advice from our own experiences, and provide feedback to Product and Project Managers to help make Zendesk better. Many Support teams, you just punch your card and answer the phone all day, but Zendesk is quite different.

Zendesk as a company is very focused on community initiatives, giving us a plethora of opportunities to volunteer in our neighborhoods.

Finally, the culture. I look forward to going to work (even on Mondays). It's amazing to look forward to seeing your coworkers and how much everyone truly appreciates the value of helping one another get the best answer to customers.
cons: Direct, constructive feedback is sometimes hard to come by, especially if you excel in your role. Sometimes "keep doing a good job" isn't quite what someone wants to hear.
advice_to_mgmt: Make sure we keep the culture as we grow. It's tough, but it truly drives so many people to WANT to excel. Not only working for the company and ourselves, but to work for and be inspired by teammates and colleagues.

pros: Company really cares about the employees. Tries to make the office and amenities as nice as possible, within reason. Transparency is a key value to the company, so we have monthly town hall meetings.
cons: Office location can be a little draining. Company offers lots of great perks, but there are still some growing pains of a younger company.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the good work and don't lose the culture as we grow.

pros:
-Amazing corporate culture
-Great work/life balance
-Upward mobility
-Comprehensive benefits
-Flat-ish hierarchy
cons:
-Midmarket location is a bit sketchy (on the street only - office is very secure)
-No 401k matching
advice_to_mgmt: Work to maintain open communication channels and avoid losing the company culture during these periods of fast growth

pros: If you've ever wanted to work for a company that does the right thing, you've found your place. In a cut-throat software world, Zendesk still abides by the idea that it wants to make your consumer life in dealing with customer service the best it can humanly be. Great message, great software, done right. Near the top on employee benefits
cons: This is not a sales culture and that can possibly be a detriment to the company in the long run. This is a product focused company striving to find their core audience and companies that have the same mindset.
advice_to_mgmt: Stick to your guns. While the technology is incredible the people are what got you to the top. Don't abandon that by hiring people with 'resume experience' and overlook the importance of toughness, passion, and grit when it comes to Customer Service. A lot of that already exists internally at Zendesk.

pros:
I have been here for a little over a year now:

- Great team/co-workers
- Great office/environment (inside office)
- Quickly expanding - very exciting times
- New C-level execs are fantastic
- Fantastic ESPP plan (pay is average, but total compensation plans are great)
cons:
- SF office location is alright...
- Growing pains (re-orgs...many of them)
- no defined career growth paths
- Pay is average in market
advice_to_mgmt:
- Inter-departmental/internal announcements would be great
- Develop and invest in your current employees (define and set career paths) for all departments
-

pros: Coming from a non-tech background and having an opportunity to learn the industry and hold several positions that have helped advance my career, I can honestly say that Zendesk has provided opportunities that I would not have had otherwise. In an individual contributor role, my primary interactions are with our customers, our sales team, and our product team, all of which are fantastic to work with. Culture and work/life balance are super important and valued highly. In a company where the founders are still an integral part of day-to-day after 9 years, the trust in the C-level team is incredibly high.
cons:
VP level leadership has taken some significant mis-steps, causing pain for those under them, but on the whole have made positive contributions.

Benefits are good, but no 401k match.

pros:
- Company culture: everyone is great and easy to work with! I can't think of a single person I hate to work with.

- Perks! HH's, snacks, occasional catered lunches, annual company events (SKO in Whistler, annual picnic, Zendesk Club)
cons: - would like more insight from upper management on the future of Zendesk and career path
advice_to_mgmt: clearer career path

pros: Really great work/life balance and culture. No matter how big we grow, Zendesk puts effort into keeping the Zendesk feel in everything we do. The people are smart and dedicated, the products are great, and the company is strong.
cons: Missing some perks like 401k matching and gym membership. While the office is very safe, the surrounding area isn't the best.
advice_to_mgmt: Always remember to maintain transparency and fairness.

pros: Good company culture, work life balance, if you get your work done in this company you are given a lot of freedom, good leadership, transparent career ladder so you can grow your career, company is growing, great offices, good feedback loop on your performance, smart coworders
cons: The benefits are probably less than some other companies in the same sector

pros: Love the culture of my team and the company overall
cons: Office location and career progression can be very unclear
advice_to_mgmt: Improve career progression to high performance employees

pros: Really good pay, relaxed culture, smart people, good work/life balance
cons: Typical growing pains of a fast-growing tech company
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the good work. Keep working to solidify vision

pros: The relations between departments in the Madison office are very cooperative and quite out of the ordinary compared to other jobs I've had. Pay is mostly competitive, benefits are good to great, and management seems genuinely willing to listen to new ideas.
cons: Zendesk can be a bit nice and shy away from having some of the tough conversations. We also suffer a bit from lack of followthrough after initial excitement for a new idea wears off. While Madison has great communication between departments, this is not necessarily true between different branches/regions.
advice_to_mgmt: Management would benefit by learning how to have tough conversations and hold people to standards to make a good workplace even better.

review_title: Fun place, cool people, interesting work
pros: If you get get your work done, management is supportive of managing your day as needed. I have had good resource and career support in my years at Zendesk.
cons: Middle management seems to be getting heavy. Not enough doers, but a lot of people that talk a big game, and don't really do the work.
advice_to_mgmt: Let's stick to the old credo of hiring A players. We are a great company - we shouldn't settle for hiring people with inflated titles.

review_title: Great start-up on the way to Corporacy
pros: The benefits are great and they respect your work-life balance a lot. If you're into volunteering, there's a lot of opportunities.
cons: The worst con is the lack of promotion for people doing the hard work. You're more likely to get promotions and bonuses by doing office politics than good work. The company is also more focused on creating new features than taking care of the old ones. Zendesk used to be driven by engineers, now it's driven by product managers.
advice_to_mgmt: Give more bonuses to the engineers doing extra good work and reward their constant work with promotions.

pros:
- Good product
- Good customers
- Good CEO
cons:
- Not a good CRO
- Major growing pains in the sales org
- Cliques
advice_to_mgmt: Do not let a new CRO implement a half baked idea without having a fully formed plan.

pros: Insane amounts of autonomy and creative freedom. Great culture. Fantastic management (facilitators, not micromanagers).
cons: Very distributed organization structure, still figuring out cohesion. Growing pains of any recent IPO company.
advice_to_mgmt: Help facilitate more insight and communication between teams. So many great people and projects here, but as an employee I'm not always aware of everything.

pros:
The culture and people are typical "startup" - vibrant atmosphere with lots of office perks, casual attire, and the people are really the best. They are all super-smart, interesting, and some don't come from a typical IT background. They can be very passionate and opinionated but having come from some places where people don't really care about their work or their customers, I would definitely rather be surrounded by people who care too much than not enough. The teamwork and collaboration is really great also.

As is common with small technology companies, they are constantly changing so that they can try new things and adapt to what is needed.
cons:
If you don't like a fast paced atmosphere with constant change, this company is not for you.

It can sometimes seem like it's disorganized, and it's getting so big that communication between departments can be challenging.

There is no 401K matching at this time.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep doing what you're doing - keep it fun, honest, and ambitious! Also, please match our 401K contributions.

review_title: Needs a very strong leadership as the company grows larger
pros:
- Opportunity to work on an interesting projects
- Company has a very good culture especially in the tech industry
- Majority of the organization provides a very well work-life balance
- Company has a solid product
cons:
- Introduction of mid level managers are usually signs of uncertainty of direction
- Needs a very strong leadership as the company is entering the enterprise world
- The company has turned into a sales driven company instead of engineering first company, which is very normal to see in a big enterprise world. Unfortunately this is a very tough and uncomfortable situation especially in the engineering organization
- The office is unfortunately located in a rather sketchy and unfriendly neighborhood especially for those who are not local
advice_to_mgmt:
- Be very careful when introducing mid level management as it might be a very dangerous and poisonous if not put in a proper place.
- A strong leader is not always friends or families.

pros: Great Product, Solution, and Technology, very user-friendly, and intuitive
cons: Moving into expedited growth mode changes the culture of the company reducing sales opportunities, number of accounts, territory.

review_title: Innovative and Emerging Tech Company with Truly Zen-like Culture
pros:
-Vibrant, fun, witty office culture. The workday is full of laughs and good times.
-Little hierarchy in organization structure. Employees have a good deal of autonomy to share and implement ideas.
-Great perks - lunches, happy hours, amazing office location, extensive snack selection
cons:
-No 401K matching, which is certainly unusual for a successful tech company
-Confusing network of parking benefits, without benefits for green and self-powered commuters
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the transparent and empowering company culture, but consider improving retirement and commuter benefits!

review_title: Great company to be a part of!
pros:
-Lots of opportunities to contribute in areas that are of interest to you.
-Paths for career advancement.
-All leadership is highly engaged and approachable.
-Direct management invests time in you and is always open to feedback.
-Awesome office space with so many amazing snacks and beverages!!
-Committed to making a difference in the local community with frequent opportunities to volunteer.
cons: There are not many, this the first company I've been at where I'm not thinking about my next move. If I needed to pick something, it would be that some departments work better as a cross-functional partner than others.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue to invest in people, it makes all the difference in long term career satisfaction!

pros:
+ Have never seen a company so genuinely walk the talk when it comes to "employee first" culture
+ Positive set of benefits - parking, PTO, equity
+ Great work / life balance
+ Any tool you need to be productive is available to you
cons:
- Zendesk has grown quickly and tremendously, lots of new faces and everything is changing all the time (product, organization, senior leaders)
- No 401(k) match is the only benefit gap ... but still kind of table stakes for a company of this size
- For a global company, all big decisions are made in SF ... but at least the company welcomes travel to SF so you don't feel out of the loop
advice_to_mgmt: Keep protecting the culture despite the pressures faced by a public company - growth, profit, etc. Mikkel does great at that but a new C-Staff team is going to need to learn how important that truly is.

pros: Zendesk really cares about people, both customers and employees. They strongly believe in a culture that treats people like real human beings instead of just a cog in the machine and they back up that belief by spending money on it. I feel valued and respected for what I bring to the table. The corporate growth strategy seems to make sense.
cons: The company is growing rapidly. That means that change is a constant. Change can be tough to deal with and not everyone deals with it in a healthy way. Because they're going so rapidly, onboarding as a new employee could use some work (which they acknowledge and are working on).
advice_to_mgmt: Keep setting high goals for us to chase. Keep investing in the culture. Be aware of the organization's capacity for change and don't exceed it without first investing in growing the capacity for change.

pros: Fantastic culture! The VP of the Madison office (Greg Collins) is a great leader and really lives the "people first" mantra. Employees are very positive and willing to help out wherever they can. Great perks - free food, drinks and activities. Also very committed to community service and they give employees time during the day to give back to the community. Great company, SO happy to be there.
cons: A lot of young kids right out of school are going to be super disappointed if they have to change jobs - other companies just aren't like this! Zendesk is growing fast and they need to ensure they are growing smart, not just growing.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue to protect the culture - it's great and employees seem very happy. Continue to empower and trust in your people as you've done thus far.

review_title: Career Growth and Work Life Balance!
pros: I've worked here for ~3 years, have learned so much, and have been recognized for my hard work and accomplishments. No company has ever provided me with the opportunities to grow my career quite like Zendesk, all the while maintaining my sanity! Great people, great products, and a great future here.
cons: 401K matching would be nice, but the stock options more than make up for it.

pros:
- work/life balance - many companies talk the talk, Zendesk actually walks the walk
- smart coworkers who want to do the right thing for the company and our customers
- casual culture where having a personality (and showing it) is an asset
- work is challenging and impactful yet the workload is manageable
cons: - no 401k matching at this time

pros:
+ Fantastic work-life balance. Work from home as necessary so long as you're getting your job done
+ Amazing recruitment team -- they find/hire intelligent, driven, passionate people who are diverse yet are great cultural fits
+ A great people-first leadership mentality which derives from our CEO and permeates most of the management through the company. Zendesk really does care about growing their own.
cons:
- High rate of growth has contributed toward less transparency for organizational/departmental decisions.
- High rate of growth drive towards continued growth has the compounding effect of siloing relationship building within teams
advice_to_mgmt: Trust your employees. We hire a lot of really intelligent and creative people, so don't feel like you need all of the answers or that it's a show of weakness not knowing something. Continue driving the people-first mentality and empowering the amazing talent we have and the sky's the limit.

pros: A lot of companies talk about a work-life balance, Zendesk achieves it. People show up at reasonable times and leave at reasonable times. The CEO makes it a point not to offer dinner as people should go home and unwind. Benefits package is strong but still misses common pieces. Annual soccer tournament that gives people a fun day to unwind as an organization.
cons: No matching 401k is the only thing left on my list of making this a perfect a workplace. But don't let that stop you, as your mental health is worth more than just $$$.

pros: Terrific supportive culture. Great place to work with lot's of opportunity to contribute positively.
cons: Lot's of moving parts here.
advice_to_mgmt: Great job investing in our future with great people. Excited to be part of the opportunity to grow and succeed.

pros:
People want to be here.
The break room is fully stocked with almost everything you could ever need.
No Windows workstations.
cons: There is a long onboarding period while learning all the different pieces that makeup Zendesk and who is responsible for each component.

pros:
Great work environment
smart, hardworking and inspiring people
diverse
international
amazing product
great CEO
cons:
growing hierarchies
lack of processes, strucuture and organization in some departments
constant restructuring/re-organization
advice_to_mgmt: Find ways to make long-term employees stay

pros:
- Good work-life balance
- Great people
- good pay
- Interesting work / a lot to learn (however this last pro is very dependent on your team, some other interns don't feel the same way)
cons:
- Some of the work that interns do can be somewhat routine (I have not experienced this personally but other interns have)
-The internship program is great in a lot of ways and the hr/recruiting staff have been awesome. However, there haven'y been that many intern events. We mostly have to make the effort to get to know each other

pros:
Love that the onboarding process went off without a bang. Everyone was organized and ready to go right down to the training materials and tools.

Also love the people who work here, they really dont hire jerks!
cons: In transition and trying to move up stream to a more enterprise style sale. There will definitely be growing pains
advice_to_mgmt: Just ensure a smooth transition from your core business and beyond

review_title: Best decision was to accept a job at Zendesk
pros:
Recruiting process- great communication throughout. 2 phone interviews and 2 onsite interviews with varies members of the team and extended leadership team

Work: challenging but rewarding. Great teams that are collaborative and data driven.

Leadership- transparent and aligned.
Work life balance.
cons:
The business is shifting and we may not have the right talent to get us there. There are people who have been around for a while and may not be up for the challenge.

Systems are decentralized so getting a single source of truth on data is difficult.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep the Zendesk culture alive and continue to be transparent with us. We look up to you for guidance.

pros: -awesome environment, friendly team, passionate employees, positive
cons: none that I can think of

review_title: Best company I've ever worked for...
pros: Amazing company tops-down: culture, leadership, vision, alignment, talent, etc.
cons: haven't seen anything in my short time.

review_title: Good place to work, depending on the department
pros:
The company is growing, the top leaders are there to grow the company and see it through. Minus some of the comments in the 'Cons' section, there are a lot of good and smart people there. The creative team, support team, HR, C-Level executives, and others but these stand out.

If you want to brand your company, look at what Zendesk has done over the years, they are MASTERS!

The product - is AMAZING and they just keep making it better!

Company is still growing and is a company to watch!
cons:
As the company started to grow, they were hiring leaders from big companies but having the best and with the proper experience come on board. Thus, caused issues with learning curves and new challenges that should have not been there if they hired more qualified mid-level leaders. These leaders then in turn brought in weaker people and thus crating a poor working environment.

The different groups have very strong clicks that will alienate new people and other that are no in their own department. Some of the people, especially in marketing and sales, are straight out rude and seem not to have very high moral value.

Pricing of the product is always a topic for people looking to use Zendesk and I know many companies now that want to use Zendesk but don't because of the pricing and go with another system. These are enterprise level companies too.
advice_to_mgmt: if you want to crush the competition, then make sure your price up front, not the sales team, allow for discounts or to smooth the price out. You have an amazing product, get people to use it and stick with it, keep the price simple and sweet.

pros: Friendly and helpful content marketing team.
cons: there's not too much instruction

pros: Great culture, for a fast growing, well-funded startup. Zendesk worked hard to maintain a balanced work-hard play-hard culture. The founders brought a great Euro vibe which was a welcome change from the more typical and more aggressive Silicon Valley/tech culture.
cons: Some could argue that the rapid growth of the company was very fun and exciting, but as one who likes the ability to get to know the people I work with and amongst, growing that fast makes it hard to feel like you're part of a family.
advice_to_mgmt: It's tough to provide advice on how to better manage growth when the goal is growth; versus the goal of focusing on building great teams, great products, and having those core focuses yield growth.

pros:
Zendesk is a very rare company to work for in the sense that is rapidly approaching being a true "grown-up" enterprise software with arguably the best product of it's type in the market, yet they remain true to the culture that got them where they are today.

People first, or more accurately the right people first: meaning that doing whats best for the customer/employee/community takes precedent over doing what will benefit the share-holders. The idea here that by doing the right thing, in as many aspects as possible, the company will benefit as a byproduct. Not only is this an idea that resonates with me personally, with today's increasingly socially-minded consumers, it will likely continue to resonate with the market.

I know I am not alone in saying, that "Zendesk Family" (this includes our customers too!) feel less like job/business and more of a culture or a literal family, and on that you would willingly try your best to see do well.

Plenty of opportunity. Plenty of truly good people. Couldn't be happier building my career here
cons:
When I started there, it was like a person in that awkward "transition period" before being able act, and feel, like an adult. Almost like the freshman sports star that realized the talent alone that got them there would not be enough to keep having the success they have grown to expect. It would take being smarter. Better processes. More leadership.

While I have seen a dramatic (it's crazy really) improvement in this regard, they know that improvements can always be made.

Because of this, if you are not good at adapting to an ever-changing environment, or willing to try something new, possibly just to scrap it just as you started getting used to doing so, you may not like Zendesk.
advice_to_mgmt:
I recognize managements stellar job of proving that we will not remain "that great start-up" or "the first choice for small businesses, but not viable for larger companies needs". We have proven to be able to adapt to being a true organization, and not a scrappy team with a great product. Even more so when it comes to proving to the market that the solution is more times than not, the best option for business of all sizes (Happy to go toe-to-toe with any of the alternatives, the whole lot of em').

But my only request now is to not let the "soul" of Zendesk get lost in the progression. You can't force "cool" or "caring", but do not foster an environment promotes otherwise. If I have to someday where a tie everyday, or not do whats right for the customers in the name of the almighty dollar. It would not only drive me to leave, but it would feel like having a friend completely lose track of who they are, and turn into someone you would rather not know.

review_title: Good. Can be better. Will be better.

Some less experienced leaders think that what worked for the company while in scrappy start-up mode will continue to work for this public company with over 1200 employees, and they undermine the work senior leaders are doing to take Zendesk to the next level.

The younger workforce enjoys the internal "Zendesk culture", which might be a great motivator for some but does little to actually build structure and develop individual growth; two areas which could be improved.

review_title: There are good times and there are bad times.
pros:
-I can't stress how amazing the people you work with are. They're fantastic people who you celebrate the best times with, and drink away the worst of times with.

-The office is a fantastic space with gorgeous views. The in-office perks are pretty fantastic

-As long as you're doing your job, you can pretty much coast by and do a so-so job and still get somewhere in the company (get a raise/promoted/bonus).

-It's a relatively young office; so co-workers are always open to getting drinks after work.
cons:
Where do I start:
-There is not a standard set of expectations for employees company-wide. Employees who work in larger departments need to work harder to shine; while those in smaller departments who are absolutely terrible at their job can either get promoted/raises/bonuses pretty easily.

-Employees can do a terribly at their job, and still get promoted due to a lack of applicants/talent for jobs. The same can be said for people in their position a prolonged period of time. I'm not saying this is the case for all employees, but it really degrades the title of your position. My advice to anyone going into support is to do your time, get to know the hiring managers in other departments, tailor your time in support to where you want to end up, and get out of support as soon as you can.

-There is no pay scale implemented at all. Team leads can sometimes make less than those on their teams; there no standardization when it comes to pay. There can be an alarming gap between employees who hold the same title. Some employees with a job title that is in a tier below another can make the same, if not more than an employee in a higher tier of the same department. You're better off not telling anyone what you make, or asking what others make (because good luck getting that pay bump).

-There's definitely a considerable amount of politicking that goes on in the background, and it doesn't help the employees at all. The company could use a little more transparency rather than sugar-coating unpleasant news.

-It's a relatively young office; so some questionable decisions are bound to be made.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep doing what you're doing if you want to become the next Epic. You're not working people to death by any means; but the mental stress that goes into putting up with your "initiatives" is something else. You're hiring the right people, but the way company is treating them is another issue. For a company whose product is customer service, the employees who support the product are definitely at the bottom of the totem pole in the company.

review_title: a dream job at a dream company

40-something founders and management team means that they've been there before and have a level of maturity and focus that is rare in startups. CEO cares so deeply about customers, community and employees as opposed to his own ego or riches. Laughter and joy are the most common emotions expressed.

Customers LOVE LOVE LOVE Zendesk, even if our product (and people) aren't perfect. When a customer tells us they are leaving for a competitor, we actually help them do it, and treat them with respect and care on their way out. And they often come back when they realize they'be been duped.

Nobody in the company is satisfied with any aspect of the product, company, design or culture. This gives us all a sense of "kaizen" (continuous improvement) which is very healthy. Plus the Zen thing is more than a fat Buddha on the website, it's weirdly (and appropriately) weaved throughout our culture.

And I get to say curse words all the time and people don't get uncomfortable. The "old timers" who were there at the beginning are very welcoming of newer people which is rare.

I could go on and on....

Sales/marketing culture may over-power original product/engineering/support culture, which is fine, but needs to be effectively managed. Amazing contributors (and there are many) need to realize they are amazing and not feel somehow marginalized.

Politics, competition and positioning is minimal and work/life balance is something that is encouraged and supported. The other stuff, like perks, conditions and environment are second to none, but these hold nothing against the quality of our people and leaders.

Put it this way. Every Sunday night I have a serious TGIM moment. I genuinely look forward to kicking off every new week. No TGIF here.
cons:
Note: the following statement is not really a con...

I am in a highly specialised role, and a solo operator in my region, so whilst the traditional opportunities for progression may not be as plentiful as they would be in a huge conglomerate, I have numerous other opportunities.

The wonderful trade-off is that I get to progress my career in an environment that encourages risk-taking and innovation. All that stuff I wanted to try in my last jobs, I get to play with and try at Zendesk.

So whilst I might not be fast labelled with a lofty, ego-stroking title, I am given endless opportunities to experiment and explore and have a real impact on the people I work with every day.
advice_to_mgmt:
You're doing an awesome job. We're at one of the hardest points of organisational development, and we're talking about all the right things.

It's a million times easier to make a 2/5 into a 3/5, than making a 4.4/5 into a 4.5/5.

Stay connected to the people. Tell great stories. Keep being courageous.

So...don't go changin'.

review_title: Very poor middle management...such a shame for an otherwise good company
pros:
Inspirational CEO, laid back and in touch with the workforce.
Great product, much loved by customers around the world
Strong branding and marketing
Good work / life balance
Strong community spirit and CSR
Bootcamp is of very high standard
Some really nice and friendly individuals
cons:
Terrible middle management for the most part, in particular at VP and DIrector level : old school techniques not aligned with Zendesk's startup spirit.
Turnover at management level translated into very little coaching and guidance .
Completely unrealistic sales target with a blanket approach for the whole team regardless of what territory you work on, your level of senority and so on.
Territories are constantly changing (every quarter), which makes it very difficult to build long term relationships with clients and prospects.
The picture painted during my interviews and the reality were quite different.
Cliquey atmosphere that does not come across as being very real
I personally did not like the offices, which are right next to the Crossrail building site, in a not so desirable area of Paddington.
It's common for probation periods to last up to a year, which is just not right in my opinion. If you've hired someone, you should be able to tell if they are right for the job in the first 6 months.
advice_to_mgmt: Treat your sales people with more respect. Don't ignore them when you see them in the corridor ! Take an interest in what they do. As a sales manager, it's your job to motivate your troops, and it's's a daily job, not a once in a quarter effort. Tailor your salespeople's objectives to their territories and book of business. It's no fun to work in sales and only achieve a fraction of your quota because your targets are crazy high. Give them clear objectives and work with them on achieving them.

review_title: One Implementation Specialist's View of Zendesk
pros: Zendesk provides a great environment for self-fulfillment and improvement. There are many opportunities and it is relatively open to exploring my interests even if they fall outside of my specific role. For example, I am passionate about learning foreign languages and as a company that has clientele around the globe, there are many conversations in non-English languages. I've been successful at getting myself into many of those conversations even though I was not directly hired for it. Zendesk also has an inclusive and welcoming environment. I have worked at the office in Madison and in Singapore and both have felt this way. The company organizes many events and is inclusive of all employees to participate. There is also an awesome feeling of empowerment both on the job and in the larger community. CSR is an important part of our job and even though I don't participate as much as others, it feels great to see our CEO so active. Lastly, it is open in terms of rank and file employees approaching management or senior management to express concerns or to socialize.
cons: As a new company, many policies and procedures are not clearly defined, frequently change, or are simply not good. I think that as it is raplidly growing there is also constant change, which can be good for the opportunity it provides, but also bad as the structure can often be insufficient. There is also a lot of change as Zendesk continues transitioning away from start-up mentality (1600+ employees) to more corporate: more bureaucracy, more inflexible policies, more segmentation and siloing of responsibilities. Though these can be good things in ways, they can also be very negative for one seeking the openness and flexibility of startup.
advice_to_mgmt: Work on providing more clearly defined structure to employees so they can be more certain about their position, their responsibilities, limitations and extent of duties, and company policies so that they can focus on doing awesome things. Also, don't lose the charm of the lean Danish start-up that has made Zendesk so attractive.

review_title: Looks good from the outside but don't let that fool you
pros: Some nice people within the company. Cool office and central location for the London office. Nice clients to work with.
cons: It's a startup and as with all startups, it either works or is doesnt. Zendesk management is not capable of planning ahead and calculating budgets which leaves us with mega targets. Lately a lot of people have been hired only to be fired again when the company finds out there is no budget (bad planning). There is no proper HR as they are not certified and experienced enough to function as an actual HR department so you might as well discuss HR issues with the cleaner. There are no contracts either so you basically don't have a leg to stand on. Recruitment is currently eating out of their nose and seem to hire everyone that is interested but not qualified. The recruiters that did add value and were easy to talk to or ask questions to have been kicked out due to budgetting. Have seen some very lovely people go and will probably leave pretty soon myself. It kind of feels like being on the titanic which can sink any day now.
advice_to_mgmt: Hire qualified people who have done the work for a few years before, not just those that come from the competitior as that doesn't always mean they are right for the job. Change your management and your HR/Recruitment for more qualified people who actually know what they are doing.

review_title: Only a politician has better spin and PR, the ugly truth behind not so Zen desk UK.
pros:
Some of the people are genuine and have a really warm manner and heart.

You have access to a fridge of food from Sainsburys each day but this gets emptied by the sales team at 12 noon leaving the rest to fight for scraps.

There are soft drinks and snacks which you can avail of.

The product is for the most brilliant but is on a downward trend as they cannot iron out the speed issues and other long standing kinks.
cons:
Where to begin...

Globally
=====

Well like any American company the head office Americans have all the fun. Everywhere else is neglected unless we have a visitor then its all smiles and positive PR. This may explain the mixed reviews and gushing. If it is a gushing review its likely a San fran employee.

Also there is a lot of politics and "who you know" culture.

It is plain to see this is a start up trying to grow up. The problem is that they have lots of staff managing who are now out of their depth. They seem to be in a bubble of their own hype and self importance and no one seems to do anything to fix it.

I have seen several high profile comings and goings (CTO level downward) and it is all spun with happy happy joy joy PR (as most things are with Zendesk). The dark truth of some of these departures is worrying particularly the way employees are fired. Never seen anything like it and I question the legality in some cases as there is still no HR handbook or in fact a proper HR structure.

I have also seen some unbelievably talented employees throw in the towel after a number of years, being pushed out by those I began describing in lower management.

It really is all about who you know and that couldn't be more evident than at Zendesk.

UK specific
=====

In support team meetings and personal 1-1 reviews are often ignored / cancelled. Great for morale of the team. Points raised in meetings are often ignored only to be brought up several weeks later as either a managers idea or something that an American suggested on one of the infinite number of meetings that seem to have no point or purpose.

Morale is very low and has been for some time. There is no bonus culture here and the pay is poor. Any rise if you get one is 3% which translates to about £40 extra a month after tax.

I could go on to be honest but my advice if you are thinking about joining this company in the UK is go in prepared for disappointment and keep your eyes open to other opportunities elsewhere. There are certainly better paying gigs in London with a similar vibe.

If you want a career don't join this company. They have a small marketing dept, a big sales dept with unrealistic targets, a small services team that hires externally (their own dev friends) and a support team that is very understaffed and has been for a number of years. If you need it spelled out there is nowhere for you to move into to further your career and that's not going to change as Dublin is their Euro HQ. London is a sales hub.
advice_to_mgmt:
Get rid of managers who are not capable at growing teams to match business requirements.

Stop ignoring failure of managers

Increase wages

Insist that 1-1 meetings and salary reviews actually take place

Give people bonuses

Give more opportunities and clear out the mouthpieces fond of their own voice and self praise wrapped up in their own hype
